articles.headline: In Liberal San Francisco, Tech Leaders Brawl Over Tax Proposal to Aid Homeless
articles.snippet: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Marc Benioff of Salesforce, among others, are sparring over a Nov. 6 ballot initiative that would impose new corporate taxes.
articles.abstract: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Marc Benioff of Salesforce, among others, are sparring over a Nov. 6 ballot initiative that would impose new corporate taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, technology companies in San Francisco have fought a local ballot proposition that would impose taxes on corporations to fund initiatives to help the homeless.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Russians of Interfering in Midterm Elections
articles.snippet: Russians working for a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin created social media accounts to pose as Americans and write posts on divisive issues including race and gender, prosecutors said.
articles.abstract: Russians working for a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin created social media accounts to pose as Americans and write posts on divisive issues including race and gender, prosecutors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russians working for a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin are engaging in an elaborate campaign of “information warfare” to interfere with the American midterm elections next month, federal prosecutors said on Friday in unsealing charges against a woman whom they labeled the project’s “chief accountant.”

articles.headline: U.S. to Tell Russia It Is Leaving Landmark I.N.F. Treaty
articles.snippet: President Trump has been moving toward leaving the treaty because Russia has been violating it and because it is constraining American efforts to counter China in the Western Pacific.
articles.abstract: President Trump has been moving toward leaving the treaty because Russia has been violating it and because it is constraining American efforts to counter China in the Western Pacific.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is preparing to tell Russian leaders next week that it is planning to exit the landmark Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, in part to enable the United States to counter a Chinese arms buildup in the Pacific, according to American officials and foreign diplomats.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Disinformation Spreads on WhatsApp Ahead of Brazilian Election
articles.snippet: Facebook, which owns WhatsApp, is trying to prove it can curb the spread of false news. But the app’s design makes it difficult.
articles.abstract: Facebook, which owns WhatsApp, is trying to prove it can curb the spread of false news. But the app’s design makes it difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past few months, the 120 million Brazilians who use WhatsApp, the smartphone messaging application that is owned by Facebook, have been deluged with political messages.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: Harvard’s Admissions Process, Once Secret, Is Unveiled in Affirmative Action Trial
articles.snippet: A lawsuit accusing one of the country’s most selective universities of discriminating against Asian-Americans is providing a glimpse into how admissions officers decide “yea” or “nay.”
articles.abstract: A lawsuit accusing one of the country’s most selective universities of discriminating against Asian-Americans is providing a glimpse into how admissions officers decide “yea” or “nay.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The deliberations that take place inside 86 Brattle Street, a red brick building where Harvard University’s admissions committee convenes, have very much stayed inside 86 Brattle Street.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Says Jamal Khashoggi Was Killed in Consulate Fight
articles.snippet: The kingdom’s public prosecutor said Mr. Khashoggi died after an argument and fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
articles.abstract: The kingdom’s public prosecutor said Mr. Khashoggi died after an argument and fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After two weeks of shifting stories, Saudi Arabia said Saturday that its agents strangled Jamal Khashoggi, a dissident journalist, during a fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul and that 18 men had been arrested in the case.

articles.headline: Something New May Be Rising Off California Coast: Wind Farms
articles.snippet: The Interior Department is moving to lease parcels in the deep Pacific waters for development, which could help the state meet its clean-energy goals.
articles.abstract: The Interior Department is moving to lease parcels in the deep Pacific waters for development, which could help the state meet its clean-energy goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California’s aggressive pursuit of an electric grid fully powered by renewable energy sources is heading in a new direction: offshore.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Republicans Find a Facebook Workaround: Their Own Apps
articles.snippet: Conservative political apps deliver curated partisan messages, free from the strictures and content guidelines imposed by Silicon Valley giants.
articles.abstract: Conservative political apps deliver curated partisan messages, free from the strictures and content guidelines imposed by Silicon Valley giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine a society in which everyone more or less agrees with you.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Saudis’ Image Makers: A Troll Army and a Twitter Insider
articles.snippet: The kingdom silences dissent online by sending operatives to swarm critics. It also recruited a Twitter employee suspected of spying on users, interviews show.
articles.abstract: The kingdom silences dissent online by sending operatives to swarm critics. It also recruited a Twitter employee suspected of spying on users, interviews show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each morning, Jamal Khashoggi would check his phone to discover what fresh hell had been unleashed while he was sleeping.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Mark Mazzetti, Ben Hubbard and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Saudi Explanation of Jamal Khashoggi’s Killing Fails to Squelch Skepticism
articles.snippet: As doubts swirled about the Saudi account that the dissident journalist was strangled during a fight, an explanation emerged about the presence of a doctor of forensic medicine at the killing.
articles.abstract: As doubts swirled about the Saudi account that the dissident journalist was strangled during a fight, an explanation emerged about the presence of a doctor of forensic medicine at the killing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s explanation on Saturday only added to the international uproar over the killing of the dissident Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul. President Trump appeared to step back from an earlier expression of confidence in this new description of events that Mr. Khashoggi was strangled after a fistfight — skeptics focused on apparent gaps in the narrative and Turkey threatened to undermine the already shaky Saudi account with its own rival investigation.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: G.O.P. Candidates Struggling in Key Battlegrounds, With House at Stake
articles.snippet: Party leaders worry that candidates for governor and Senate are in trouble in Michigan, Illinois, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and possibly Wisconsin, and that difficulties could spill into House races.
articles.abstract: Party leaders worry that candidates for governor and Senate are in trouble in Michigan, Illinois, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and possibly Wisconsin, and that difficulties could spill into House races.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Republican leaders are increasingly worried that their candidates for governor and Senate are in political trouble across Michigan, Pennsylvania, Minnesota and other states that the party prizes, and that the difficulties could spill into House races that the G.O.P. needs to win in November to keep control of the chamber.

articles.headline: ‘Transgender’ Could Be Defined Out of Existence Under Trump Administration
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is considering a legal definition of gender as immutable and fixed at birth, the most drastic in a series of moves against transgender people.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is considering a legal definition of gender as immutable and fixed at birth, the most drastic in a series of moves against transgender people.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering narrowly defining gender as a biological, immutable condition determined by genitalia at birth, the most drastic move yet in a governmentwide effort to roll back recognition and protections of transgender people under federal civil rights law.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green, Katie Benner and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Josh Hawley, Missouri Senate Candidate, Oversees an Office in Turmoil
articles.snippet: Mr. Hawley, who is challenging Senator Claire McCaskill, has been Missouri’s attorney general for less than two years. His tenure has been rocky.
articles.abstract: Mr. Hawley, who is challenging Senator Claire McCaskill, has been Missouri’s attorney general for less than two years. His tenure has been rocky.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Josh Hawley’s tenure as Missouri’s attorney general has been brief. And turbulent.

articles.headline: A Push for Safer Fertilizer in Europe Carries a Whiff of Russian Intrigue
articles.snippet: A proposed environmental regulation has become an unlikely source of geopolitical tension, raising concerns about Russian influence over Europe’s food supply.
articles.abstract: A proposed environmental regulation has become an unlikely source of geopolitical tension, raising concerns about Russian influence over Europe’s food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The trade group Safer Phosphates would seem to have a pitch-perfect message for an environmentally conscious European Union. It advocates cleaner soil and healthier food, with a website showing pristine fields of wheat. It is also supporting legislation that would place tighter regulations on fertilizer.

articles.headline: Miscarrying at Work: The Physical Toll of Pregnancy Discrimination
articles.snippet: Women in strenuous jobs lost their pregnancies after employers denied their requests for light duty, even ignoring doctors’ notes, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.abstract: Women in strenuous jobs lost their pregnancies after employers denied their requests for light duty, even ignoring doctors’ notes, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Women in strenuous jobs lost their pregnancies after employers denied their requests for light duty, even ignoring doctors’ notes, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: As Democrats Court Latinos, Indifference Is a Powerful Foe
articles.snippet: Democratic Party strategists hope Latino voters angered by the administration’s rhetoric and policies will help deliver resounding victories.
articles.abstract: Democratic Party strategists hope Latino voters angered by the administration’s rhetoric and policies will help deliver resounding victories.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Children ripped from their parents’ arms and held in sweltering tent cities. Immigration raids outside hospitals, schools and courthouses. An onslaught of ads and speeches delivering insults and racist remarks.
articles.byline: By Jose A. Del Real and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Turkey’s President Vows to Detail Khashoggi Death ‘in Full Nakedness’
articles.snippet: In taking on the Saudis over Jamal Khashoggi’s death, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan may be fighting a larger, geopolitical battle.
articles.abstract: In taking on the Saudis over Jamal Khashoggi’s death, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan may be fighting a larger, geopolitical battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turkish officials have been leaking lurid details for weeks about the assassination and reported dismemberment of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi in the kingdom’s consulate in Istanbul. But President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, keen to maintain good relations with Saudi Arabia, has until now mostly held his tongue.

articles.headline: Blumhouse Studio, Scary at the Box Office, Gets Serious About TV
articles.snippet: The Hollywood producer of blockbuster films like the latest “Halloween” sequel is trying to become a serious player in television. It won’t be easy.
articles.abstract: The Hollywood producer of blockbuster films like the latest “Halloween” sequel is trying to become a serious player in television. It won’t be easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood studio Blumhouse knows how to make hit movies: Produce a film on the cheap, market it to audiences who love horror, and then sit back and watch the huge box office results roll in. It worked for “Paranormal Activity,” “The Purge” and “Get Out.” The latest example, its “Halloween” sequel, took in $77.5  million over the weekend for one of the best openings in horror film history.

articles.headline: The Next Tech Talent Shortage: Quantum Computing Researchers
articles.snippet: By some estimates, only 1,000 or so researchers can claim to understand the technology. Finding more could become a national security issue.
articles.abstract: By some estimates, only 1,000 or so researchers can claim to understand the technology. Finding more could become a national security issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christopher Savoie, founder and chief executive of a start-up called Zapata, offered jobs this year to three scientists who specialize in an increasingly important technology called quantum computing. They accepted.

articles.headline: At the Border Town That the News Cycle Has Left Behind
articles.snippet: When the algorithms that drive social media move on, the children who were separated from their parents remain in detention facilities along the Rio Grande.
articles.abstract: When the algorithms that drive social media move on, the children who were separated from their parents remain in detention facilities along the Rio Grande.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — After long hours at his day job, Sergio Cordova was driving home to pick up supplies and clothing for the tired and hungry asylum seekers who were camped out just a few miles away, in Matamoros, Mexico, waiting to be let in.

articles.headline: Richard Parsons Steps Down as Interim Chairman of CBS
articles.snippet: Mr. Parsons, who took the post just a month ago, is leaving because of illness. The change comes as CBS is trying to move past various scandals.
articles.abstract: Mr. Parsons, who took the post just a month ago, is leaving because of illness. The change comes as CBS is trying to move past various scandals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard D. Parsons, a longtime media executive who less than a month ago was named the interim chairman of CBS to help stabilize the company, said on Sunday that he was stepping down because of illness.

articles.headline: Trump’s Plans to Deter Migrants Could Mean New ‘Voluntary’ Family Separations
articles.snippet: New policies to deter illegal immigration include a plan that would ask migrants to choose between their children and longer detention.
articles.abstract: New policies to deter illegal immigration include a plan that would ask migrants to choose between their children and longer detention.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — The Trump administration, facing a surge in migrant families entering the United States, is moving swiftly to examine an array of new policies it hopes will deter Central Americans from journeying north.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan, Caitlin Dickerson and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Jon Tester Is a Big Guy in Big Sky Country. He Hopes That’s Enough.
articles.snippet: Once considered a favorite in the contest for his Senate seat in Montana, Mr. Tester is now at risk.
articles.abstract: Once considered a favorite in the contest for his Senate seat in Montana, Mr. Tester is now at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUTTE, Mont. — Jon Tester, the senator who looks least like a senator, sized up a crowd of dozens and got to talking about history.
